notes.text:
CHIEF COMPLAINT:
45 year old male presents with acute left flank pain radiating to groin, onset 3 hours ago. Reports gross hematuria and nausea.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient has history of recurrent kidney stones. Last episode was 2 years ago, passed spontaneously. Denies fever or dysuria. Pain is 8/10, colicky in nature.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
- Nephrolithiasis (multiple episodes)
- Hypertension
- Type 2 Diabetes

MEDICATIONS:
- Lisinopril 10mg daily
- Metformin 500mg BID

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
Vitals: BP 142/88, HR 92, Temp 98.6F
Abdomen: Soft, left CVA tenderness present
No peritoneal signs

LABS:
WBC 11.2, Cr 1.1, UA with 50+ RBCs

IMAGING:
CT KUB shows 5mm left distal ureteral stone with mild hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
1. Acute left ureteral colic
2. 5mm distal ureteral stone
3. Will trial conservative management with hydration and pain control
4. Discussed increasing fluid intake to 2-3L daily
5. Strain urine for stone analysis
6. Follow up with urology in 1 week if not passed

CT ABDOMEN AND PELVIS WITHOUT CONTRAST

CLINICAL INDICATION: Flank pain, rule out nephrolithiasis

TECHNIQUE: Helical CT of the abdomen and pelvis without IV contrast. DLP: 587.08 mGy-cm

FINDINGS:

KIDNEYS: The right kidney measures 11.2 cm and is unremarkable. The left kidney measures 10.8 cm. There is a 5 x 2 x 4 mm calculus in the left distal ureter at the ureterovesical junction. Mild left hydroureter and hydronephrosis proximal to the stone.

No right-sided stones identified. No perinephric stranding.

BLADDER: Unremarkable.

OTHER: No acute intra-abdominal pathology. Liver, spleen, pancreas, and adrenals are unremarkable.

IMPRESSION:
1. 5 x 2 x 4 mm left distal ureteral stone at UVJ with mild proximal hydroureteronephrosis
2. No right-sided nephrolithiasis

OPERATIVE NOTE

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Left ureteral stone
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Same

PROCEDURE: Left ureteroscopy with laser lithotripsy and stent placement

SURGEON: Dr. Smith

ANESTHESIA: General

FINDINGS: 6mm stone in left proximal ureter

PROCEDURE DETAILS:
Patient placed in dorsal lithotomy position. Cystoscopy performed with 22 Fr rigid cystoscope. Left ureteral orifice identified. Guidewire passed under fluoroscopic guidance.

A 9.5 Fr semirigid ureteroscope advanced to the proximal ureter where a 6mm stone was visualized. 200 micron holmium laser fiber used at settings of 0.8J and 10Hz. Stone fragmented completely. Fragments extracted with 2.4 Fr stone basket.

A 6 Fr x 26 cm double-J ureteral stent placed. Position confirmed with fluoroscopy.

EBL: Minimal
COMPLICATIONS: None

POSTOP PLAN:
- Stent removal in 1 week
- Strain urine
- Follow up in clinic

UROLOGY CLINIC FOLLOW UP

Patient is a 45 year old male here for follow up after left ureteroscopy with laser lithotripsy.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
Procedure was 10 days ago. Stent was removed 3 days ago. Patient reports mild dysuria that has improved. No fever, no hematuria currently. Passed some small stone fragments.

Stone analysis returned: 80% calcium oxalate monohydrate, 20% calcium phosphate.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Denies flank pain, fever, nausea. Reports good oral intake.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vitals: BP 128/82, HR 72
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender
No CVA tenderness

24-HOUR URINE RESULTS:
Volume: 1.8L (goal >2.5L)
Calcium: 320 mg/day (elevated)
Oxalate: 45 mg/day (normal)
Citrate: 380 mg/day (low)
Sodium: 280 mEq/day (elevated)
pH: 5.8

DIETARY RECOMMENDATIONS:
1. Increase fluid intake to maintain urine output >2.5L daily
2. Reduce sodium intake to <2300mg daily
3. Moderate protein intake
4. Increase citrus fruit consumption
5. Avoid excessive oxalate (spinach, nuts, chocolate)

MEDICATIONS:
- Starting potassium citrate 10mEq BID

FOLLOW UP:
Repeat 24-hour urine in 3 months. Annual KUB to monitor for recurrence.

CHIEF COMPLAINT:
52 year old female with known cystinuria presents with right flank pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient has history of cystinuria diagnosed at age 25. Has had multiple stone surgeries including bilateral PCNLs. Currently on tiopronin. Reports 2 day history of right-sided pain, similar to prior stone episodes. Also reports passing 2 small stones at home last week which she saved for analysis.

Her stone burden has been increasing on surveillance imaging. Last CT 3 months ago showed interval stone growth with new 8mm right lower pole stone.

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Lives alone, works as teacher. No transportation issues. Reports difficulty affording tiopronin at times.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
Vitals stable
Right CVA tenderness

CT FINDINGS:
8mm right lower pole stone, stable. New 4mm right UPJ stone causing mild hydronephrosis.

PLAN:
1. Admit for pain control and hydration
2. Urology consult for possible intervention
3. Social work consult for medication assistance programs
